elements.content: A new carboxylato-bridged CoII network of formula {Co((κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4-TDC)(μ2-H2O)0.5(H2O)} n (H2TDC = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and IR and UV−visible spectroscopies. The title compound is made of chains of CoII dimers interconnected by TDC2- ligands, showing an unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate coordination mode of the carboxylate functions. Magnetic measurements show weak ferromagnetic interactions between the Co ions within the dimers.
elements.clean_text: A new carboxylato-bridged CoII network of formula {Co((κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4-TDC)(μ2-H2O)0.5(H2O)} n  (H2TDC = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and IR and UV-visible spectroscopies. The title compound is made of chains of CoII dimers interconnected by TDC2- ligands, showing an unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate coordination mode of the carboxylate functions. Magnetic measurements show weak ferromagnetic interactions between the Co ions within the dimers.

elements.content: A new carboxylato-bridged CoII network of formula {Co((κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4-TDC)(μ2-H2O)0.5(H2O)} n (H2TDC = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and IR and UV−visible spectroscopies. The title compound is made of chains of CoII dimers interconnected by TDC2- ligands showing an unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate coordination mode of the carboxylate functions. Magnetic measurements between room temperature and 1.8 K show weak ferromagnetic interactions between the Co ions within the dimers, which couple antiferromagnetically below 16 K.
elements.clean_text: A new carboxylato-bridged CoII network of formula {Co((κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4-TDC)(μ2-H2O)0.5(H2O)} n  (H2TDC = 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid) has been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and IR and UV-visible spectroscopies. The title compound is made of chains of CoII dimers interconnected by TDC2- ligands showing an unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate coordination mode of the carboxylate functions. Magnetic measurements between room temperature and 1.8 K show weak ferromagnetic interactions between the Co ions within the dimers, which couple antiferromagnetically below 16 K.

elements.content: Syntheses, structures, and properties of coordination polymers still arouse considerable research interests because of their potential applications in materials science. Carboxylic acids have been successfully used as building blocks for the design of various coordination polymers, in areas such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensors, and magnetism.
elements.clean_text: Syntheses, structures, and properties of coordination polymers still arouse considerable research interests because of their potential applications in materials science. Carboxylic acids have been successfully used as building blocks for the design of various coordination polymers, in areas such as gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensors, and magnetism.

elements.content: Following our research on the grafting of thiophenecarboxylates into layered magnetic transition-metal hydroxides5 and in order to overcome the difficulty encountered for the anionic exchange of 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2TDC) into cobalt hydroxide layers, we have extended our approach to the direct synthesis of extended polymeric magnetic networks incorporating the TDC2- ligand. The magnetic properties of such extended networks have been very scarcely studied. To the best of our knowledge, only one recent paper reports the magnetic properties of two Co- and Fe-based compounds built from the combination of TDC2- with 4,4‘-bipyridine.
elements.clean_text: Following our research on the grafting of thiophenecarboxylates into layered magnetic transition-metal hydroxides5 and in order to overcome the difficulty encountered for the anionic exchange of 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (H2TDC) into cobalt hydroxide layers, we have extended our approach to the direct synthesis of extended polymeric magnetic networks incorporating the TDC2- ligand. The magnetic properties of such extended networks have been very scarcely studied. To the best of our knowledge, only one recent paper reports the magnetic properties of two Co- and Fe-based compounds built from the combination of TDC2- with 4,4‘-bipyridine.

elements.content: It has been shown that H2TDC shows various binding modes such as monodentate, bridging bidentate, or bridging tridentate, which makes it a useful building block in the elaboration of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text: It has been shown that H2TDC shows various binding modes such as monodentate, bridging bidentate, or bridging tridentate, which makes it a useful building block in the elaboration of coordination polymers.

elements.content: Several one-, two-, or three-dimensional MnII, CoII, CuII, and ZnII compounds have been obtained by mixing H2TDC and N ligands. 1-D polymeric chains have been obtained with this ligand and triorganotin. Finally, 2-D and 3-D metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been reported with TbIII 2 or CuII. In these MOFs, the TDC2- ligand exhibits a symmetric tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode.
elements.clean_text: Several one-, two-, or three-dimensional MnII, CoII, CuII, and ZnII compounds have been obtained by mixing H2TDC and N ligands. 1-D polymeric chains have been obtained with this ligand and triorganotin. Finally, 2-D and 3-D metal organic frameworks (MOFs) have been reported with TbIII2 or CuII. In these MOFs, the TDC2- ligand exhibits a symmetric tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-κ1)-μ4 coordination mode.

elements.content: We report here the synthesis, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of a new CoII(TDC) compound, where TDC2- exhibits the unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode.
elements.clean_text: We report here the synthesis, crystal structure, and magnetic properties of a new CoII(TDC) compound, where TDC2- exhibits the unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4 coordination mode.

elements.content: The title compound {Co(TDC)(H2O)1.5} n (1) was synthesized as dark-pink crystals by a hydrothermal method from CoCl2·6H2O (0.48 g, 2 mmol), H2TDC (0.34 g, 2 mmol), and NaOH in water (2 mol·L-1, 20 mL) in a sealed bomb (125 mL) at 180 °C over 22 h. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. Its structure consists of 1-D chains of octahedral CoII dimers, organized in layers parallel to the (b,c) planes and connected to one another via the TDC2- units along the a axis (Figure and the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: The title compound {Co(TDC)(H2O)1.5} n  (1) was synthesized as dark-pink crystals by a hydrothermal method from  CoCl2⋅6H2O (0.48 g, 2 mmol), H2TDC (0.34 g, 2 mmol), and NaOH in water (2 mol⋅L-1, 20 mL) in a sealed bomb (125 mL) at 180 °C over 22 h. 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. Its structure consists of 1-D chains of octahedral CoII dimers, organized in layers parallel to the (b,c) planes and connected to one another via the TDC2- units along the a axis (Figure  and the Supporting Information).

elements.content: ORTEP view of compound1. The ellipsoids enclose 50% of the electronic density. The water molecules are labeled O3 and O7. Symmetry operators for equivalent positions are as follows:  a = 1 − x, y, 3/2 − z; b = 1 − x, 2 − y, 1 − z; c = x, 2 − y, 1/2 + z; d = 1/2 + x, −1/2 + y, 1 + z; e = 3/2 − x, −1/2 + y, 3/2 − z; f = 3/2 − x, 3/2 - y, 2 − z; h = 1/2 + x, 3/2 - y, 1/2 + z.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP view of compound1. The ellipsoids enclose 50% of the electronic density. The water molecules are labeled O3 and O7. Symmetry operators for equivalent positions are as follows: a = 1 - x, y, 3/2 - z; b = 1 - x, 2 - y, 1 - z; c = x, 2 - y, 1/2 + z; d = 1/2 + x, -1/2 + y, 1 + z; e = 3/2 - x, -1/2 + y, 3/2 - z; f = 3/2 - x, 3/2 - y, 2 - z; h = 1/2 + x, 3/2 - y, 1/2 + z.

elements.content: All of the CoII ions are crystallographically equivalent and lie in a slightly distorted octahedral environment consistent with the UV−visible spectrum (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The axial positions are occupied by two water molecules, whereas the equatorial positions are occupied by four O atoms from four different TDC2- groups. Two CoII ions are bridged by two (κ1-μ2)-carboxylate groups, forming the repeating dinuclear unit. These diamond-core dimers are then connected along the c axis by two (κ1-κ1)-carboxylate functions and one bridging water molecule. The distances between the metal centers within the chain are 3.212 and 3.583 Å in and between the dimers, respectively. Finally, one interchain and two intrachain hydrogen-bonding interactions are found respectively between an O atom of the bidentate carboxylate and a terminal water molecule of another chain (O5···O3 = 2.747 Å) and between the H atoms of the two water molecules and the noncoordinated O atom of the monodentate carboxylate group (O6···O7 = 2.642 Å and O6···O3 = 2.813 Å) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Accordingly, the C1−O6 bond length is not as short as expected for a terminal C−O (C1−O6 = 1.247 Å).
elements.clean_text: All of the CoII ions are crystallographically equivalent and lie in a slightly distorted octahedral environment consistent with the UV-visible spectrum (Figure S5 in the Supporting Information). The axial positions are occupied by two water molecules, whereas the equatorial positions are occupied by four O atoms from four different TDC2- groups. Two CoII ions are bridged by two (κ1-μ2)-carboxylate groups, forming the repeating dinuclear unit. These diamond-core dimers are then connected along the c axis by two (κ1-κ1)-carboxylate functions and one bridging water molecule. The distances between the metal centers within the chain are 3.212 and 3.583 Å in and between the dimers, respectively. Finally, one interchain and two intrachain hydrogen-bonding interactions are found respectively between an O atom of the bidentate carboxylate and a terminal water molecule of another chain (O5⋅⋅⋅O3 = 2.747 Å) and between the H atoms of the two water molecules and the noncoordinated O atom of the monodentate carboxylate group (O6⋅⋅⋅O7 = 2.642 Å and O6⋅⋅⋅O3 = 2.813 Å) (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). Accordingly, the C1-O6 bond length is not as short as expected for a terminal C-O (C1-O6 = 1.247 Å).

elements.content: Each chain of dimers is connected to four other chains in the a direction by TDC2- ligands. Each TDC2- ligand thus exhibits two different modes of coordination of its carboxylate units. One carboxylate function is monodentate and coordinated to two Co ions (κ1-μ2) in one chain; the other carboxylate function is in bridging bidentate mode (κ1-κ1). This tetradentate asymmetric coordination mode is observed for the first time in complexes with the TDC2- ligand (Table ). Based on the Cambridge Crystallographic Database, this asymmetric coordination mode of carboxylate functions is rare. To our knowledge, two examples of cobalt and zinc benzenetetracarboxylate show the two coordination modes (κ1-κ1) and (κ1-μ2), but no dicarboxylate ligand having this (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4 coordination has ever been described.
elements.clean_text: Each chain of dimers is connected to four other chains in the a direction by TDC2- ligands. Each TDC2- ligand thus exhibits two different modes of coordination of its carboxylate units. One carboxylate function is monodentate and coordinated to two Co ions (κ1-μ2) in one chain; the other carboxylate function is in bridging bidentate mode (κ1-κ1). This tetradentate asymmetric coordination mode is observed for the first time in complexes with the TDC2- ligand (Table ). Based on the Cambridge Crystallographic Database, this asymmetric coordination mode of carboxylate functions is rare. To our knowledge, two examples of cobalt and zinc benzenetetracarboxylate show the two coordination modes (κ1-κ1) and (κ1-μ2), but no dicarboxylate ligand having this (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4 coordination has ever been described.

elements.content: Coordination Modes of the Carboxylate Functions of TDC2-

Compound 1 was also investigated by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (Figure S4 and Table S2 in the Supporting Information). A broad feature is observed in the 3300−3500 cm-1 region and is attributed to the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the coordinated water molecules, whereas the band at 1630 cm-1 is attributed to their bending mode. The asymmetric stretching band of the carboxylate function, νas(COO), is almost not modified in 1 compared to Na2(TDC) (1565 and 1560 cm-1, respectively), whereas the symmetric stretching band is clearly split in two in 1 [1390 and 1345 cm-1 in 1 and 1385 cm-1 in Na2(TDC)]. These two Δν values [Δν = νas(COO) − νs(COO)] can be attributed respectively to the bridging bidentate coordination mode (κ1-κ1) (Δν = 175 cm-1) and to the bridging monodentate coordination mode (κ1-μ2) (Δν = 220 cm-1) of the carboxylate functions of TDC2-. The other bands observed between 1460 and 1540 cm-1 are attributed to in-plane ring vibrations.
elements.clean_text: Compound 1 was also investigated by Fourier transform IR spectroscopy (Figure S4 and Table S2 in the Supporting Information). A broad feature is observed in the 3300-3500 cm-1 region and is attributed to the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching modes of the coordinated water molecules, whereas the band at 1630 cm-1 is attributed to their bending mode. The asymmetric stretching band of the carboxylate function, νas(COO), is almost not modified in 1 compared to Na2(TDC) (1565 and 1560 cm-1, respectively), whereas the symmetric stretching band is clearly split in two in 1 [1390 and 1345 cm-1 in 1 and 1385 cm-1 in Na2(TDC)]. These two Δν values [Δν = νas(COO) - νs(COO)] can be attributed respectively to the bridging bidentate coordination mode (κ1-κ1) (Δν = 175 cm-1) and to the bridging monodentate coordination mode (κ1-μ2) (Δν = 220 cm-1) of the carboxylate functions of TDC2-. The other bands observed between 1460 and 1540 cm-1 are attributed to in-plane ring vibrations.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 reveals four successive weight losses in the temperature range 30−900 °C (Figure ). The first one, between 160 and 300 °C, is related to the dissociation of coordinated water molecules (obsd 10.7%; calcd 10.6%). The second one, from 300 to 410 °C, corresponds to the exothermic dissociation and combustion of the C6H2S moiety (obsd 42.1%; calcd 41.5%). The exothermic peaks just above 470 °C are due to the oxidation of CoII to CoIII with the loss of one O atom (obsd 6.2%; calcd 6.2%). The product obtained between 470 and 600 °C is amorphous; it is necessary to increase the temperature to 710 °C to lose 5/3 O atoms (obsd 10.1%; calcd 10.4%) and to form the cobalt oxide Co3O4 (the nature of which has been checked by powder X-ray diffraction). The final fractional weight of the Co3O4 residue is in agreement with the expected Co content in 1 (obsd 22.7%; calcd 23.0%).
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 reveals four successive weight losses in the temperature range 30-900 °C (Figure ). The first one, between 160 and 300 °C, is  related to the dissociation of coordinated water molecules (obsd 10.7%; calcd 10.6%). The second one, from 300 to 410 °C, corresponds to the exothermic dissociation and combustion of the C6H2S moiety (obsd 42.1%; calcd 41.5%). The exothermic peaks just above 470 °C are due to the oxidation of CoII to CoIII with the loss of one O atom (obsd 6.2%; calcd 6.2%). The product obtained between 470 and 600 °C is amorphous; it is necessary to increase the temperature to 710 °C to lose 5/3 O atoms (obsd 10.1%; calcd 10.4%) and to form the cobalt oxide Co3O4 (the nature of which has been checked by powder X-ray diffraction). The final fractional weight of the Co3O4 residue is in agreement with the expected Co content in 1 (obsd 22.7%; calcd 23.0%).

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 in the 295−1.8 K range is shown in Figure . Between 295 and 150 K, the χT product follows the Curie−Weiss law with a Curie constant of 3.53 emu·K·mol-1 in agreement with high-spin CoII ions in octahedral geometry and a positive Weiss temperature (θ = 2.63 K) indicating ferromagnetic interactions.
elements.clean_text: The temperature dependence of the magnetic susceptibility of 1 in the 295-1.8 K range is shown in Figure . Between 295 and 150 K, the χT product follows the Curie-Weiss law with a Curie constant of 3.53 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 in agreement with high-spin CoII ions in octahedral geometry and a positive Weiss temperature (θ = 2.63 K) indicating ferromagnetic interactions.

elements.content: χT vs T curve for 1 recorded under a 0.05 T applied field.
elements.clean_text: 3  χT vs T curve for 1 recorded under a 0.05 T applied field.

elements.content: Accordingly, the slight increase of the χT product from room temperature (3.44 emu·K·mol-1) to 135 K (3.61 emu·K·mol-1) suggests the presence of weak ferromagnetic interactions between the Co ions within the dimeric subunits. The subsequent decrease to 45 K and the almost constant value of χT down to 16 K (3.40 emu·K·mol-1) may indeed be rationalized in considering the spin−orbit coupling of the CoII ions, which stabilizes a pseudo-spin value S = 1/2 for each CoII ion at low temperature. The associated g value of 5.2 determined from the magnetization at high field (2.6 μB; Figure ) is within the expected range. The ferromagnetic coupling within the dimeric subunits leads to consideration of magnetic entities with a pseudo-spin value S = 1 and g = 5.2 resulting in χT = 3.38 emu·K·mol-1 that matches the experimental value of χT = 3.40 emu·K·mol-1 at the plateau. Finally, the decrease of χT below 16 K may be attributed to antiferromagnetic coupling between the dimers within the chain and/or between the chains.
elements.clean_text: Accordingly, the slight increase of the χT product from room temperature (3.44 emu⋅K⋅mol-1) to 135 K (3.61 emu⋅K⋅mol-1) suggests the presence of weak ferromagnetic interactions between the Co ions within the dimeric subunits. The subsequent decrease to 45 K and the almost constant value of χT down to 16 K (3.40 emu⋅K⋅mol-1) may indeed be rationalized in considering the spin-orbit coupling of the CoII ions, which stabilizes a pseudo-spin value S = 1/2 for each CoII ion at low temperature. The associated g value of 5.2 determined from the magnetization at high field (2.6 μB; Figure ) is within the expected range. The ferromagnetic coupling within the dimeric subunits leads to consideration of magnetic entities with a pseudo-spin value S = 1 and g = 5.2 resulting in χT = 3.38 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 that matches the experimental value of χT = 3.40 emu⋅K⋅mol-1 at the plateau. Finally, the decrease of χT below 16 K may be attributed to antiferromagnetic coupling between the dimers within the chain and/or between the chains.

elements.content: Magnetization cycle for1 at 5 K (black) and 1.8 K (red).
elements.clean_text: 4  Magnetization cycle for1 at 5 K (black) and 1.8 K (red).

elements.content: The magnetization vs field at a sweeping rate of 1 mT·s-1 at 5 K does not show any hysteresis, whereas at 1.8 K, a small opening is observed between 0.8 and 4.3 T (Figure ). Such a feature has already been observed for polynuclear paramagnetic compounds and attributed to a phonon bottleneck phenomenon.
elements.clean_text: The magnetization vs field at a sweeping rate of 1 mT⋅s-1 at 5 K does not show any hysteresis, whereas at 1.8 K, a small opening is observed between 0.8 and 4.3 T (Figure ). Such a feature has already been observed for polynuclear paramagnetic compounds and attributed to a phonon bottleneck phenomenon.

elements.content: We have described here the hydrothermal synthesis and structure of a new CoII coordination polymer in which the TDC2- ligand exhibits an unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate coordination mode (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4. The overall magnetic behavior of this compound is antiferromagnetic, but a weak ferromagnetic coupling is observed between two CoII linked by two μ2-O of two TDC2- ligands. The coordination properties of TDC2- with other transition-metal ions in the same reaction conditions are under investigation in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text: We have described here the hydrothermal synthesis and structure of a new CoII coordination polymer in which the TDC2- ligand exhibits an unprecedented asymmetric tetradentate coordination mode (κ1-κ1)-(κ1-μ2)-μ4. The overall magnetic behavior of this compound is antiferromagnetic, but a weak ferromagnetic coupling is observed between two CoII linked by two μ2-O of two TDC2- ligands. The coordination properties of TDC2- with other transition-metal ions in the same reaction conditions are under investigation in our laboratory.

cln_elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) for 1 reveals four successive weight losses in the temperature range 30−900 °C (Figure ). The first one, between 160 and 300 °C, is related to the dissociation of coordinated water molecules (obsd 10.7%; calcd 10.6%). The second one, from 300 to 410 °C, corresponds to the exothermic dissociation and combustion of the C6H2S moiety (obsd 42.1%; calcd 41.5%). The exothermic peaks just above 470 °C are due to the oxidation of CoII to CoIII with the loss of one O atom (obsd 6.2%; calcd 6.2%). The product obtained between 470 and 600 °C is amorphous; it is necessary to increase the temperature to 710 °C to lose 5/3 O atoms (obsd 10.1%; calcd 10.4%) and to form the cobalt oxide Co3O4 (the nature of which has been checked by powder X-ray diffraction). The final fractional weight of the Co3O4 residue is in agreement with the expected Co content in 1 (obsd 22.7%; calcd 23.0%).

metadata.title:
Structure and Magnetic Properties of a New Cobalt(II)
Thiophenedicarboxylate Coordination Polymer Showing Unprecedented
Coordination
